Award.AwardTitle: Developing Teaching Expertise in K-5 Mathematics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Developers and researchers at the University of Michigan and the State University of New York, Buffalo are engaged in a project to design materials and an accompanying support system to enable the development of expertise in the teaching of mathematics at the elementary level. The project has four main components: a set of online professional development modules; practice-based assessments; a set of resources for facilitators; and web-based technologies to deliver module content to diverse settings. Three modules are planned: one focused on fractions and one focused on reasoning and explanation designed by Deborah Ball, Hyman Bass and the University of Michigan development team; and one on geometry developed by Douglas Clements and Julie Sarama at the University of Buffalo, State University of New York. Each module is organized into ten 1.5 hour sessions.

Each module goes through a two-year design and development process that includes initial design, piloting, revision, and dissemination. Modules are piloted in a variety of settings, including university based courses for practicing teachers and district based in-service activities. These contexts include face-to-face professional development, real-time distance learning, and combinations of the two. Data are collected on participant engagement with the modules, on teacher classroom practice, and on mathematical knowledge for teaching.

The modules and associated materials will be widely available and will be free to schools. The materials can be imported into any learning management system, such as Blackboard, Moodle, and others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of education lacks a system of professional development that can reliably equip teachers with the professional knowledge and skills needed to help all students achieve today’s ambitious standards for mathematics learning. Furthermore, although there is considerable demand for skilled facilitation of teacher professional development, there are few resources and learning opportunities for facilitators to develop the knowledge and skills needed for this work. Our project addressed these problems both conceptually and practically by creating widely available modules to support high quality professional development that allows for access to expert teacher educators, while also increasing the capacity of local facilitators.

Through this research and development project, we produced modules designed to enhance the expertise of elementary mathematics teachers by providing them with experiences that integrate professional knowledge of mathematics, insight into student thinking, and skills with high-leverage teaching practices. The modules were specially designed to offer robust professional development sessions, made possible through the use of multimedia records of expert teacher educators facilitating professional learning, along with frequent opportunities to connect back to teachers’ own classrooms and practice through the use of protocols for learning in and from teaching. While modules are facilitated by onsite professional development leaders, access to multimedia records depicting expert teacher educators serves to scaffold facilitation demands and also provide professional learning opportunities for professional development leaders.

This project generated several important findings. First, the project demonstrated that it was possible to use a consistent design to produce professional development modules integrating very different combinations of mathematics, pedagogy, student thinking, and professional learning protocols. Second, it was possible to use a combination of common web designs and newly developed web-based applications, such as a project-developed media player, to put multimedia content at the fingertips of facilitators for use with professional development participants. Third, while novel in its approach, diverse facilitators working in many different contexts were able to use the modules with integrity. Fourth, teachers participating in the modules demonstrated significant gains in their mathematical knowledge illustrating that an integrated approach to professional content can occur without undermining the learning mathematics for teaching. Fifth, that facilitators and teachers were able to recognize the value in building their capacities to learn in and from teaching as an outcome of participation in a professional development module.

The materials and findings resulting from this project have the potential to reshape both the content and delivery of inservice teacher professional education. The online modules specify core elements of professional knowledge and contribute to the development of a shared language describing mathematics teaching practices. The model of collaborative authoring of modules builds capacity within the mathematics education community for harnessing existing expertise to develop materials with a predictable structure that can provide teachers and facilitators with greater access to important work in the field. The project enhanced the infrastructure for research and education in professional development by providing a vision for how professional development with integrated content can be designed and made widely accessible.
